title.narrative: Bangladesh: Combating Labor Trafficking through Awareness Raising and Enhancing Victim Protection

description.narrative: Through its Bangladesh field office, the Solidarity Center (SC) currently implements a J/TIP-funded anti-trafficking in persons (TIP) program to address labor recruitment abuses, raise awareness among vulnerable migrant and garment workers, and assist victims. Given the scope of the problem, the proposed project will aim to enhance and institutionalize anti-TIP efforts, particularly for forced labor. To ensure program sustainability and maximize effectiveness, SC proposes a 24-month, $500,000 program to raise awareness on TIP and enhance victim protection in Bangladesh among migrant workers who are particularly vulnerable. The objectives are to 1) promote safe migration through education and awareness raising, and 2) enhance victim protection, including greater access to justice. The combination of activities to educate workers, formalize civil society/government networks, and strengthen rule of law (through the implementation of rules for anti-TIP laws and enhanced legal protection efforts) will contribute to program sustainability by institutionalizing anti-TIP systems. SC will continue to partner with and provide technical assistance to two of the leading local migrant rights organizations, the Bangladesh Ovibashi Mohila Sramik Association (BOMSA) and the Welfare Association for the Rights of Bangladeshi Emigrants-Development Foundation (WARBE), which will implement primary community outreach and advocacy efforts, as well as an additional long-term partner, the Bangladesh National Women Lawyers Association (BNWLA), which will provide legal and referral support for TIP victims. The project will leverage established relationships with local government officials and police in target districts to bolster existing efforts.

title.narrative: Combating Human Trafficking in Bangladesh through the Promotion of Safe Migration and Protection

description.narrative: Relief International will combat human trafficking in Bangladesh through the promotion of safe migration and protection of victims. Project activities will include building the capacity of existing government institutions to train potential migrant workers on safe migration, human trafficking, government sanctioned recruitment processes, and existing anti-trafficking laws; generating awareness on safe migration and human trafficking among potential migrants; and identifying, rescuing, and rehabilitating trafficking victims through partnerships with local NGOs and service providers.

title.narrative: Technical Assistance to the Government of Bangladesh in Strengthening the Responses to Human Trafficking

description.narrative: This project is a joint initiative of the UNODC and the Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of Bangladesh. The project aims to assist the Government of Bangladesh in preventing human trafficking through effective and strengthened law enforcement capacities and by providing protection and assistance to trafficked victims through establishment of national referral mechanisms and increased cooperation between the criminal justice system and civil society. Over a two-year period, the project seeks to: (i) Train law enforcement officials and public prosecutors in victim identification, investigation, prosecution of labor trafficking offenses and referrals for appropriate treatment and reintegration of labor trafficking survivors; (ii) Strengthen and Operationalise specialized Anti Human Trafficking Units to address trafficking with a focus on labor exploitation; (iii) Carry out a country assessment on the current situation of victim support providers; (iv) Develop guidelines for setting up a national referral mechanism for improved civil society and law enforcement cooperation; and (v) Provide protection services for adult male trafficking victims.
